options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom discussions and office hours
N/A
The class was solely in a virtual seminar format.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I continued developing my poetry writing skills
I learned to build upon and improve the forms of poetry I was already familiar with writing and to explore new ones through engagement with old and new poets who are successful in their work.
An eye for particular weaknesses in my writing, formal strategies for approaching poetry, and exposure to various poets. Inclusion in a wonderful community of fellow poets.
Developed poetry practice, worked on style + form
I learned how to read and write poetry.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Zarin is a great instructor the class works well as is

Poetry seminars are always lovely atmospheres for focused engagement with your own writing and this class was no exception. That being said, I felt that the course could have been improved through stronger planning/structure -- namely, regular written feedback from the instructor and written feedback from classmates for workshops.
I think the course optimized the virtual platform in the best way it could.
perhaps smaller meetings would have been helpful; small student group meetings outside of class to review and discuss work
The workshop format is conducive to honing craft. I like how we spent time each week discussing the works of poets and using that discussion as the starting point for workshopping.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Worked as well as could have been expected
Seminar discussions over Zoom are challenging, but I felt most of the translation of the class to a virtual format was successful.
I thought the contribution of every student each week with a poem of choice to a class anthology was a lovely way to build community and trust among each other.
I believe we made the best of a virtual semester!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes Professor Zarin is amazing
Yes, these sort of workshop classes are rare. You will get out of this course what you put into it, so if you are devoted to improving your craft, it is definitely worth taking.
Absolutely! This is well organized course and so helpful to developing poetic craft and process.
Yes, great poetry workshop. Not many requirements or assignments, but you get what you put into it
Yes! It is a great way to improve your craft.
